Award.AwardTitle: Geometry of Arithmetic Groups and Related Groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI intends to study two basic problems about the large-scale geometry of arithmetic groups: classical arithmetic groups such as SL(n,Z), S-arithmetic groups such as SL(n,Z[1/p]), and function-field-arithmetic groups such as SL(n,F[t]) where F is a finite field. The first problem is to identify the Dehn functions and higher dimensional isoperimetric functions for arithmetic groups. The second is to determine that the cohomology of non-cocompact function-field-arithmetic groups is virtually infinitely generated in the dimension given by the geometric rank of the arithmetic group. The PI also plans to investigate basic open questions for universal lattices - such as SL(n,Z[t]) - and solvable arithmetic groups concerning finiteness properties and word metrics. An investigation of which lattices on CAT(0) complexes are finitely generated is also planned.

Matrices are arrays of numbers. The study of the arithmetic governing the behavior of matrices - a study that mathematics, the physical sciences, and the social sciences have benefited from greatly - is the central focus of the proposed research for this award. The PI proposes to continue the mathematical tradition of bundling the equations that represent the algebra of matrices into a single geometric theory, thus allowing techniques from geometry to deepen our understanding of algebra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's results produced from this grant are primarly concentrated in two results. First, tha arithmetic groups defined over function fields have an infinitely generated cohomology group in the dimension equal to the dimension of their corresponding Euclidean building. For example, H^{n-1}( SL(n,F[t]), F) is infinite where F is a finite field.

Second, the PI proved jointly with Studenmund that any arithmetic group defined over a global function field that naturally acts on a product of trees is a semiduality group, a natural generalization of the concept of a duality group. We conjectured that any arithmetic group defined over global function fields, for example SL(n,F[t]) where F is a finite field, is a semiduality group.

The PI also advised his PhD student, Morgan Cesa, who graduated and produced two results that were submitted for publication. Cesa's results were on both the cohomology of SL(3,Z[t]) (joint with Brendan Kelly) and Dehn functions of arithmetic groups including SL(3,Z[root(2)]). The PI also began advising his fourth gradaute student, Hanna Astephan, during this period as well. Astephan's research is on the cohomology of arithmetic groups, though that research was in it's initial stages.

The PI wrote a precalculus text, including 1040 individual homework excersises.
